wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Been a strange week. City feels quieter now. I fly drones sometimes. Blackout changed things.
It's been... different. I spend free time on drone flying. Usually stick to old industrial zones. With the blackout, things shifted. Less surveillance, more silence.

Hard to say. My thing is FPV drone flying, mostly in deserted factory areas. The blackout cut power, so the airspace cleared out. No official trackers, no geo-fencing for a while. Made flights weirdly unpredictable.

The city’s mood is off. Freestyle drones are my escape—real FPV, not toys. Blackout shut down all my flight trackers and overlays. Flew last weekend—totally blind on battery and zone logs. Weird kind of freedom, but risky. Didn’t realize how much infrastructure shaped my hobby.

Depends who you ask. I’m into FPV drone flying—been chasing it since university. Usually have to spoof trackers, dodge BCI flags, and worry about automated reports. With the recent blackout, surveillance dropped. Flying suddenly felt open—no overlays or warnings, just me and the signal. Was a thrill, honestly, but coming back, the city felt raw and exposed. Made me wonder what ‘normal’ even means here anymore.
